reviews.strongest_line: If you switched brokerages today, how many of your clients would follow you? That number is your real brand equity.
reviews.weakest_line: The brokerage didn't build that trust. You did.
reviews.one_line_note: This is nearly perfect—only tweak is to make the gut check question the actual CTA instead of burying it mid-paragraph.

reviews.strongest_line: The fortune is in the follow-up. And as much as I wish it wasn't, it's the hardest part.
reviews.weakest_line: Because the agents who can't stomach the follow-up? They're the ones wondering why their pipeline's empty.
reviews.one_line_note: Add what specific system Eithan built to force follow-up (calendar block, VA handoff, automated reminder) so viewers know HOW to make it happen.

reviews.strongest_line: Suddenly a $2 million home costs $25K a year just to insure. That's a $2,000 monthly payment your buyer didn't budget for.
reviews.weakest_line: Insurance is killing more deals than bad inspections right now.
reviews.one_line_note: Perfect as-is, but if you want a 10, name one specific carrier Jeff uses or one zip code where he's seen this blow up three deals.

reviews.strongest_line: Because in luxury real estate, you don't get do-overs. You get one shot to show you understand the stakes.
reviews.weakest_line: The agents who close the biggest deals aren't the fastest. They're the ones who ask the right questions before they act.
reviews.one_line_note: Perfect as-is, but if you want a 10, add one specific example of the conversation Jill had that saved a deal (even anonymized).

reviews.strongest_line: A buyer walks in. They've got eight million liquid. They need to close in thirty days. Every agent in the room is salivating.
reviews.weakest_line: Full episode link in bio.
reviews.one_line_note: This is nearly perfect—only weakness is the generic podcast plug at the end instead of a sharper behavioral CTA.

reviews.strongest_line: Not 'updated kitchen' — 'the kind of kitchen where Sunday mornings stretch into afternoons.'
reviews.weakest_line: D.J. Paris runs business development for a real estate tech company in Chicago.
reviews.one_line_note: This is the best script in the batch — the novelist/journalist persona angle is brilliantly specific and immediately actionable.

reviews.strongest_line: Your college roommate just bought a house. They didn't call you.
reviews.weakest_line: The agents who win? They grieve for five minutes, then get back on the phone.
reviews.one_line_note: Perfect as-is—this hook will stop every new agent mid-scroll and the CTA is immediately actionable.

reviews.strongest_line: The seller had been watching. Testing. Waiting to see if Jay would quit like everyone else.
reviews.weakest_line: He was on a conference call with other agents celebrating wins while he was sitting there broke.
reviews.one_line_note: Perfect as-is—this is the story that stops thumbs and changes behavior.

reviews.strongest_line: The deal that makes you feel invincible is the same one that's about to wreck your next three months.
reviews.weakest_line: Data points. Not identity markers.
reviews.one_line_note: Perfect as-is—this will stop thumbs and get saves from agents who've lived this exact cycle.

reviews.strongest_line: That client comment that ruined your whole day? It hit because you already believed it.
reviews.weakest_line: The trigger is actually showing you exactly where the work needs to happen.
reviews.one_line_note: This will get massive engagement from burned-out agents—consider extending it 10 seconds to let the emotional weight land.

reviews.strongest_line: The top 1% of agents aren't better at sales. They're better at math.
reviews.weakest_line: That's not talent. That's leverage.
reviews.one_line_note: Already excellent—only tweak would be to specify one exact ChatGPT prompt in the CTA (e.g., 'Ask: What's the average DOM for listings that sold above ask in zip code 12345?').

reviews.strongest_line: You're not guessing anymore. You're war-gaming every move.
reviews.weakest_line: Tim Burrell — top producer in Raleigh — runs every offer through AI first.
reviews.one_line_note: This is nearly perfect — only tweak is to make the CTA prompt even more copy-paste ready (give them the exact first line to paste into ChatGPT).

reviews.strongest_line: The agent who apologizes first usually wins the negotiation.
reviews.weakest_line: Full episode in bio — Tim breaks down how to use AI to coach yourself through these exact moments in real time.
reviews.one_line_note: The AI mention in the CTA feels tacked on—either commit to the AI angle throughout or drop it entirely.

reviews.strongest_line: When Zillow transfers a lead, she doesn't introduce herself first — she asks when they want to see the house.
reviews.weakest_line: The $50 million producer who still answers her phone at 9 PM just said something that made me stop.
reviews.one_line_note: The hook works but could be tighter — try 'The agent who did $50M last year still answers at 9 PM. Here's what she just told me.' to get to the payoff faster.

reviews.strongest_line: The client you half-repped is the one telling the story at the dinner party.
reviews.weakest_line: But your calendar, your response time, your staging budget? They tell a different story.
reviews.one_line_note: This is nearly perfect — tighten the SETUP by cutting 'But your calendar...' and jump straight to Kristee's quote.

reviews.strongest_line: Ten bucks at Target. Five minutes before the photographer shows up.
reviews.weakest_line: Amanda Pendleton analyzes millions of listings at Zillow.
reviews.one_line_note: This is nearly perfect — only tweak is to specify 'queen size' duvet so agents know exactly what to buy.

reviews.strongest_line: When you're calling your database, are you asking for money or are you handing out gold bars?
reviews.weakest_line: Chase Craig — two billion in sales, six thousand transactions — says most agents have this backwards.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the credential flex in SETUP and jump straight to the question—the hook already earned their attention.

reviews.strongest_line: AI now knows which agents are about to leave your brokerage before you do.
reviews.weakest_line: That's not a fair fight.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the 'fair fight' line—it's the only moment that sounds like a copywriter instead of a real conversation.

reviews.strongest_line: Most agents are about to make a $50,000 mistake.
reviews.weakest_line: The agents who win Q1 are the ones who worked Q4.
reviews.one_line_note: Replace the generic 'worked Q4' line with the exact number of calls or touches Carrie makes in November—give them a benchmark.

reviews.strongest_line: She's calling the people who bought during the pandemic — their values are up, rates dropped to 6%, and they're finally not terrified of giving up that 3% mortgage.
reviews.weakest_line: Every November, the same thing happens.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the generic 'same thing happens' line and jump straight from hook to Carrie's specific play — the setup slows momentum slightly.

reviews.strongest_line: You didn't wait to feel like a real estate expert before your first listing appointment. You decided you were an agent, then learned as you went.
reviews.weakest_line: Most agents jump straight to learning editing apps or buying ring lights.
reviews.one_line_note: The setup is slightly generic — open with a specific example of an agent freezing on camera or deleting 47 takes before giving up.

reviews.strongest_line: Every agent you add isn't just another producer. It's another person who needs training, systems, leads, and your time.
reviews.weakest_line: And when I asked him about scaling, he said something that goes against everything you hear on LinkedIn.
reviews.one_line_note: Name one specific system (CRM onboarding checklist, lead routing protocol) he requires before hiring to make the advice immediately actionable.

reviews.strongest_line: I use AI to clean up my thoughts instead of generate them.
reviews.weakest_line: Most agents are trying to get ChatGPT to write their emails, their posts, their scripts.
reviews.one_line_note: Show the exact AI prompt Eithan uses after the voice memo ('Organize these thoughts into three bullet points, keep my language') to remove any guesswork.

reviews.strongest_line: Your market doesn't owe you deals. Expansion isn't betrayal.
reviews.weakest_line: A top 1% luxury agent just said Zillow saved his team.
reviews.one_line_note: Add one sentence about what zip codes he expanded into or how many agents he deployed where—makes it immediately actionable.

reviews.strongest_line: The mechanic you never question. The doctor whose advice you follow without hesitation. The hairstylist you've been seeing for ten years. They're not better salespeople. They're more trusted people.
reviews.weakest_line: So what if you stopped trying to get better at convincing people... and started getting better at being the kind of person people don't need to be convinced by?
reviews.one_line_note: The reframe question is too long and abstract — cut it to 'Stop perfecting your pitch. Start becoming someone people trust instantly.' and move faster to the CTA.

reviews.strongest_line: The email isn't rude. It's a receipt.
reviews.weakest_line: The agents closing $2B+ in luxury deals do this after every single conversation. You probably don't.
reviews.one_line_note: The hook is slightly condescending — test 'The one habit that separates $2B agents from everyone else' to reduce defensiveness and increase curiosity.

reviews.strongest_line: Because developers don't hire agents who can talk about the building. They hire agents who know the building.
reviews.weakest_line: Then tell me what you learned.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA asks them to report back instead of giving them the next tactical step after walking the property—tell them what to do with that knowledge.

reviews.strongest_line: You're not lazy for wanting boundaries. You're strategic.
reviews.weakest_line: That's not a business. That's a treadmill with a commission check.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA needs one concrete example of what to change (e.g., 'No client calls after 6pm' or 'Batch showings Tuesday/Thursday only').

reviews.strongest_line: He fed property details into an AI tool. Thirty seconds later, he had copy that wasn't just better — it was emotionally resonant.
reviews.weakest_line: While you're copy-pasting the same tired phrases about 'spacious kitchens' and 'abundant natural light,' agents who know this are selling faster.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the setup by half — the hook is strong enough to jump straight to D.J.'s story without the preamble about tired phrases.

reviews.strongest_line: This is what your house is for. This is what all the sacrifices have been for.
reviews.weakest_line: You're not selling houses. You're selling the thing that catches people when they fall.
reviews.one_line_note: The reframe line feels written by a copywriter—let Karina's actual voice carry that moment instead of poeticizing it.

reviews.strongest_line: She treats it like brushing her teeth — boring, non-negotiable, done before she can talk herself out of it.
reviews.weakest_line: A $40 million producer just admitted she's terrible at CRM.
reviews.one_line_note: Hook undersells the insight—lead with the timer/10 minutes revelation instead of the 'admission' angle.

reviews.strongest_line: The family you helped buy their first home for thirty thousand under asking. The seller you got an extra week to move out so they didn't have to put their stuff in storage.
reviews.weakest_line: Your about me video is boring because you're bragging about the wrong things.
reviews.one_line_note: Tighten the CTA to 'Write down three client wins with dollar amounts—that's your script' for even more specificity.

reviews.strongest_line: Think about your last five deals. How many came to you versus how many did you have to convince? That ratio is your real scorecard.
reviews.weakest_line: List three things you're doing to attract versus convince.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA homework is too vague—give them one specific attraction tactic to implement tomorrow morning.

reviews.strongest_line: Open ChatGPT right now. Type: 'How can I use you better for my real estate business?' And actually read what it says.
reviews.weakest_line: He's hijacking the algorithm because he asked the algorithm how to hijack it.
reviews.one_line_note: The 'hijacking' language feels forced—just say 'gaming the system' or cut it entirely.

reviews.strongest_line: Your MLS has 300 data fields per listing. You're using maybe seven.
reviews.weakest_line: You think you're competing on personality and hustle. You're actually competing on information asymmetry.
reviews.one_line_note: Name two specific underused MLS fields by name (e.g., 'seller concessions' or 'cumulative DOM') to make the homework assignment even more concrete.

reviews.strongest_line: Pull your last 90 days of sold data tonight. Drop it into ChatGPT. Ask one question about your market.
reviews.weakest_line: Not writing listing descriptions. Not generating social posts.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the two 'Not' lines in the insight—they slow momentum—and this is a 9.

reviews.strongest_line: The agents who wait for perfect? They're still waiting. The ones who started messy? They're closing deals.
reviews.weakest_line: She went from restaurant management to REALTOR of the Year in Central Florida.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the credential setup in the second line — the hook already earned the right to the insight, don't slow it down with resume building.

reviews.strongest_line: It's like walking into a poker game knowing everyone's tells.
reviews.weakest_line: Full episode in bio.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague—give them the exact prompt to paste into ChatGPT instead of 'run it through with public transaction data.'

reviews.strongest_line: The biggest investment most people ever make, and you're their guide through what feels like psychological warfare.
reviews.weakest_line: Not about murder. Not about money laundering.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the 'Not about murder' setup line — it slows the momentum when the hook already has us — and get to 'outbid eleven times' faster.

reviews.strongest_line: You're not stuck because you're taking small deals. You're stuck because you're half-assing them while waiting for the big one.
reviews.weakest_line: Think about your last small client. Did you give them the same energy as your biggest deal?
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA is too reflective — change it to 'This week: take your smallest client and treat them like your biggest. Send the follow-up text you'd send a $2M buyer.' so they have a specific action.

reviews.strongest_line: When a client texts at 9 PM? That's not an interruption — that's someone who trusted her with the biggest financial decision of their life.
reviews.weakest_line: And when I asked her about client management, she said something that stopped me cold.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the 'stopped me cold' setup line — it's unnecessary hype before a genuinely strong quote.

reviews.strongest_line: You're marketing to the wrong generation. And it's costing you six figures.
reviews.weakest_line: They want a advisor who understands their timeline, their tax situation, and their legacy plan.
reviews.one_line_note: Change 'a advisor' to 'an advisor' and this publishes as-is—the stat is sharp, the reframe is clear, and the CTA is actionable.

reviews.strongest_line: They've already decided YOU'RE their agent. The call is just logistics.
reviews.weakest_line: Most agents are converting leads. Sarah Meslowski stopped converting them entirely.
reviews.one_line_note: This is tight—only tweak is to name one specific video title Sarah made so viewers can visualize exactly what to create.

reviews.strongest_line: When interest rates drop — don't just announce it. Tell people if NOW is the time to buy, or if they should wait.
reviews.weakest_line: Kim Rittberg works with top producers, and she's blunt about this:
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the guest credential setup and go straight from hook to the 'Everyone has Google' quote — the credibility building slows momentum.

reviews.strongest_line: Your AI listings sound robotic because you're writing one sentence when you need seven.
reviews.weakest_line: Then they wonder why every listing reads the same.
reviews.one_line_note: Give one actual example of a bad one-sentence prompt vs. a good seven-sentence prompt—show don't tell.

reviews.strongest_line: You've lost touch with the joy that made you want to build this business in the first place.
reviews.weakest_line: They built an empire that doesn't require sacrificing everything else.
reviews.one_line_note: The reframe is vague — replace 'aligned' with one specific behavior change a burned-out veteran should make this week.

reviews.strongest_line: The worst that happens is they say no, and you move the F on.
reviews.weakest_line: Most agents never prospect because they treat a 'no' like a referendum on their worth.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the math example (ten calls, nine nos) and replace with Eithan's actual first cold call story—what he said, what they said, how he felt.

reviews.strongest_line: Because here's what nobody tells you: every strategy works if you give it twelve months. And almost no strategy works if you give it twelve weeks.
reviews.weakest_line: Just one strategy — relationships, door knocking, video, whatever — and the discipline to not jump ship when it feels hard at month three.
reviews.one_line_note: The 'whatever' undercuts the specificity—pick ONE example strategy and build the whole script around that instead of listing options.

reviews.strongest_line: If you can't do a full day, you do nothing.
reviews.weakest_line: DM me 'committed' and I'll send you Paul's framework for separation season.
reviews.one_line_note: The DM CTA feels like a lead magnet bait-and-switch; just tell them the three activities in the script or link to the episode.

reviews.strongest_line: You can't learn swimming from a book.
reviews.weakest_line: Then tell me what you learned that no course could've taught you.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA asks them to report back to you—change it to an action they take for themselves, not for your engagement.

reviews.strongest_line: Because here's what 45 years teaches you: people don't negotiate with strangers.
reviews.weakest_line: They walk in armed with comps and counteroffers.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA is solid but generic — add one specific question they should ask to find common ground (e.g., 'Where'd you grow up?' or 'How long have you been here?').

reviews.strongest_line: Top producers walk into listing appointments already knowing what soccer team your kids play for.
reviews.weakest_line: It's not stalking — it's smart preparation.
reviews.one_line_note: Cut the defensive 'it's not stalking' line in the caption—it plants doubt where there was none.

reviews.strongest_line: She created 200 videos over three years. They work for her 24/7.
reviews.weakest_line: You're creating content on the wrong platform.
reviews.one_line_note: Hook is weak but the body is strong—open with '85% of her business comes from one platform you're ignoring' and this is a 8.

reviews.strongest_line: That zone-out in the shower? Hypnosis. That flow state mid-workout? Hypnosis.
reviews.weakest_line: So ask yourself: what belief are you carrying that you didn't consciously choose?
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA question is too abstract — replace with one concrete belief real estate agents carry (like 'I have to work 80 hours to succeed' or 'If I'm not hustling, I'm failing').

reviews.strongest_line: Database. Response time. Daily actions. Put it where you'll see it every morning.
reviews.weakest_line: The muck? Interest rates. Inventory. What Zillow's doing. Your competitor's Instagram.
reviews.one_line_note: The three controllables need tactical depth—HOW to improve response time, WHAT daily actions, not just naming them.

reviews.strongest_line: If you're competing on brokerage brand alone, you just became invisible.
reviews.weakest_line: These agents didn't sign up to be Compass agents. But now? They're operating under a tech-forward company that moves nothing like the legacy brands they joined.
reviews.one_line_note: This is 90% identical to Script 3—pick one angle (tech gap or personal brand) and commit fully.

reviews.strongest_line: Most agents pay for tools. Top producers build them.
reviews.weakest_line: You'll be shocked how fast it happens.
reviews.one_line_note: The hook is strong but the middle is too vague—name ONE specific tool he built and show the exact AI prompt he used to build it.

reviews.strongest_line: Stop lying to yourself about what building an empire actually takes.
reviews.weakest_line: What are they doing that you're not? What are they NOT doing that you are?
reviews.one_line_note: The insight section is too long and abstract — give one concrete example of what 'alignment' looks like in practice (specific schedule, specific boundary, specific conversation).

reviews.strongest_line: That's not failure. That's tuition.
reviews.weakest_line: Every piece of advice you've ever gotten is worthless.
reviews.one_line_note: The hook overpromises and the insight stays too philosophical—give one specific mistake Jeff made with dollar amounts and exact consequences.

reviews.strongest_line: Your $2M listing that got 47 impressions as a photo? Now it's a cinematic walkthrough getting shared by buyers you've never met.
reviews.weakest_line: She uses Auto Real App.
reviews.one_line_note: This reads like a paid ad for Auto Real App — either commit to the tool review format or bury the product name deeper and lead with the transformation story.

reviews.strongest_line: You can be the top producer in your market and still be failing at the life you actually want.
reviews.weakest_line: Maybe success is 30 transactions and coaching your kid's team. Maybe it's $2M in volume and actually taking Sundays off.
reviews.one_line_note: Too vague and self-helpy—give one concrete example of what Garrett ACTUALLY changed in his business (a system, a boundary, a hire) instead of asking viewers to journal.

reviews.strongest_line: Five focused weeks now is worth three months of catching up later.
reviews.weakest_line: Pick three clients you've been meaning to reach out to.
reviews.one_line_note: Replace vague 'reach out' with a specific action (text this exact message, mail a market report, invite to coffee with this script).

reviews.strongest_line: Committed people don't negotiate with circumstances.
reviews.weakest_line: Pick one income-producing activity. Do it today. Not Monday. Today.
reviews.one_line_note: Name the activity—'call three expireds,' 'door-knock your farm,' 'text ten past clients'—generic IPAs don't move needles.

reviews.strongest_line: People don't want to leave voicemails about six-figure decisions. They want a human. Right now.
reviews.weakest_line: Think about the deals you lost because you were 'protecting your time.'
reviews.one_line_note: Add one specific story of a deal Karina won by answering — the 7pm call example is mentioned but not developed into an actual narrative.

reviews.strongest_line: She became THE agent for that world.
reviews.weakest_line: Find a niche and leverage your network.
reviews.one_line_note: Too generic—show us HOW she actually penetrated the finance world (specific event, conversation, or tactic), not just that she did.

reviews.strongest_line: A resume lists credentials. An About Me video shows personality, shows proof, shows why YOU are the call they should make.
reviews.weakest_line: The agent down the street just stole your listing. And you never saw it coming.
reviews.one_line_note: Hook creates a problem that doesn't connect to the solution—start with 'You're invisible on Google and here's the one video that fixes it' instead of a vague competitor threat.

reviews.strongest_line: In a business full of shortcuts, that's actually rare.
reviews.weakest_line: Show up. Do the work. Be straight with your clients. And success will be inevitable.
reviews.one_line_note: This is nearly identical to Script 3—either kill one or differentiate by showing a specific example of Jay doing one of these four things.

reviews.strongest_line: Your clients don't actually want to be your friends.
reviews.weakest_line: Being likable? That's table stakes.
reviews.one_line_note: The insight is solid but needs one concrete example of what professionalism looks like in action—a specific system or response time standard.

reviews.strongest_line: Feeling attacked doesn't mean you're weak; it means something inside of you is asking for attention.
reviews.weakest_line: Your next level of success doesn't require thicker skin — it requires regulation, presence, and the ability to lead when triggered.
reviews.one_line_note: Replace vague leadership language with one specific scenario (e.g., 'when your top agent quits after you dismissed their pricing concern') and give a tactical regulation technique Paul actually teaches.

reviews.strongest_line: A real estate tech analyst just said the quiet part out loud: it should be harder to become a REALTOR.
reviews.weakest_line: Higher standards mean better agents. Better agents mean better outcomes. Better outcomes mean the profession earns respect again.
reviews.one_line_note: The insight section is too abstract—add one specific licensing requirement Chris advocates for (hours? exam difficulty? mentorship?) and contrast it with one state's current laughably low bar.

reviews.strongest_line: Right now, you're competing with one hand tied behind your back.
reviews.weakest_line: So here's your question: if NAR won't build it, who will?
reviews.one_line_note: The insight section is too long and abstract—cut it in half and add one specific example of what an agent could DO differently with national MLS access tomorrow.

reviews.strongest_line: You're not a salesperson. You're the person someone trusts with their entire financial future.
reviews.weakest_line: Think about the last client you helped. Not the commission. The actual human. What did you protect them from? Write it down.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague and introspective — give them a specific action they can take with their next client interaction, not homework about their last one.

reviews.strongest_line: You're losing the deal before you even know they're mad.
reviews.weakest_line: It's like having a negotiation coach reading body language you can't even see over email.
reviews.one_line_note: Name the actual AI tool Tim uses—'AI tools that analyze emails' is too generic and kills credibility.

reviews.strongest_line: What if the thing your clients actually need isn't more perfection? What if they need someone who'll tell them the truth about what's real?
reviews.weakest_line: Your clients don't know what real looks like anymore.
reviews.one_line_note: The hook is too vague and the insight section tries to cover too much ground — pick one specific example (either the client's Pinterest obsession OR the agent's perfection trap, not both) and drill into it with a concrete story.

reviews.strongest_line: But every hour you wait, someone with half your knowledge and twice your hustle is closing YOUR deal.
reviews.weakest_line: Intelligence is a head start. Work ethic is the whole race.
reviews.one_line_note: This is the third script using the same quote — kill two of them or differentiate the angles completely because right now they're cannibalizing each other.

reviews.strongest_line: They don't need you to move fast — they need you to interpret clearly.
reviews.weakest_line: Ask yourself: are you still selling speed, or are you selling clarity?
reviews.one_line_note: The insight is strong but the CTA is a thought exercise — give them one specific thing to say differently on their next listing appointment.

reviews.strongest_line: Your buyers aren't walking away from the house. They're walking away from you.
reviews.weakest_line: The most effective agents? They present pricing as a narrative.
reviews.one_line_note: The hook promises a punch but the insight gets vague—show exactly what 'pricing as a narrative' looks like with a real example from Carrie's deals.

reviews.strongest_line: Your brain reads it as danger. And it pulls you back to what's familiar. What's safe. What's predictable.
reviews.weakest_line: And that's what memory reconsolidation and hypnosis actually do — they update the code.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague ('what behavior keeps showing up') — give one specific example pattern that burned-out veterans will recognize instantly (like avoiding follow-up calls or saying yes to every client).

reviews.strongest_line: Imagine one out of every five items at the grocery store all being made by the same company.
reviews.weakest_line: So here's your move: ask yourself what tech, what systems, what training you need to close the gap.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague—name ONE specific tech tool or system they should adopt today, not 'ask yourself.'

reviews.strongest_line: You're losing deals to agents who aren't better than you. They just show up first on Google.
reviews.weakest_line: That's your starting point.
reviews.one_line_note: The advice is too generic—tell them the THREE specific things to fix after they Google themselves (reviews, headshot, website speed, etc.).

reviews.strongest_line: The resentment you feel? That's not burnout. That's incongruency.
reviews.weakest_line: Look at the most successful agents in your market. What are they doing that you're not? What are they NOT doing that you are?
reviews.one_line_note: This is too similar to Script 2 (same guest, same theme, same vague questions) — either kill it or find a completely different angle on honest communication with a specific story.

reviews.strongest_line: You're not wrong about your skills yet. You're wrong about your starting point.
reviews.weakest_line: Kim Rittberg — six-time award winner, former Netflix marketer, TV producer for a decade — works with agents who know video matters but can't seem to make it work.
reviews.one_line_note: The MSR framework gets buried in explanation—show one real agent's before/after mindset shift instead of defining all three steps abstractly.

reviews.strongest_line: Every mistake became a system. Every failure became a filter.
reviews.weakest_line: The deal that fell apart because he didn't ask the right financing question.
reviews.one_line_note: This is Script 1 wearing a different hat—pick ONE actual mistake Jeff made with names, numbers, and the system he built from it.

reviews.strongest_line: When you help someone buy, you're not just closing a deal — you're anchoring a family.
reviews.weakest_line: Every rent check is a 100% loss. Not just for your client — for civilization.
reviews.one_line_note: The 'civilization' angle is too grand and preachy for stuck intermediates who need tactical wins — reframe around one specific client story where ownership changed their behavior in 90 days.

reviews.strongest_line: Your database doesn't trust you because you haven't been consistent long enough.
reviews.weakest_line: Drop it in the comments if you're serious.
reviews.one_line_note: This is a near-duplicate of Script 3 with the same Garrett quote—either kill it or differentiate by focusing on ONE specific lead source he committed to and what happened month by month.

reviews.strongest_line: The gap between you and them? It doesn't widen in January. It widens right now.
reviews.weakest_line: This December — make five extra calls a day. That's it. Five.
reviews.one_line_note: Five calls to WHO about WHAT—expired listings, past clients, sphere—specificity turns this from a 5 to an 8.

reviews.strongest_line: Every tenant becomes a future buyer. Every family she helps tells ten more.
reviews.weakest_line: What problem exists in YOUR market that every other agent is ignoring?
reviews.one_line_note: The motel conversion story is interesting but too vague — needs numbers (how many units? what's the ROI? how many referrals actually came from it?).

reviews.strongest_line: Clients don't buy your marketing stack. They buy your reliability. Your honesty. Your presence.
reviews.weakest_line: Show up. Do the work. Be straight with your clients. And success will be inevitable.
reviews.one_line_note: The advice is too generic—give one specific example of what 'show up' or 'do the work' actually looks like in Jay's daily routine.

reviews.strongest_line: Right now, you lose clients because you can't serve them past your MLS boundary.
reviews.weakest_line: With a national system, you become the advisor for their entire journey.
reviews.one_line_note: This is a policy wish, not an actionable insight—pivot to what agents can do NOW with existing tools (Zillow API, referral networks, multi-MLS subscriptions) instead of waiting for NAR to fix it.

reviews.strongest_line: Most burned-out agents aren't doing too much. They're feeling too little.
reviews.weakest_line: She told me if anybody would've said in 1999 that she'd have her name on a shirt sponsoring teams, she wouldn't have believed it.
reviews.one_line_note: The little league shirt detail is filler—replace it with a specific story of HOW gratitude changed her behavior in one transaction or tough moment.

reviews.strongest_line: We turned a privilege into a grind. A calling into a checklist.
reviews.weakest_line: Think about the last client you helped. Not the commission. The actual human. Write down their name.
reviews.one_line_note: This is nearly identical to Script 1 — same guest, same quote, same vague CTA about 'thinking about your last client' — consolidate or kill one.

reviews.strongest_line: Your buyer just asked if they could write a letter to the seller's dead mother.
reviews.weakest_line: That's not a client problem. That's the job.
reviews.one_line_note: The hook is killer but the script never delivers on it—give us one real story from an agent who saw this level of crazy, not just book summary.

reviews.strongest_line: The rage isn't anger at clients. It's anger at the impossible standard you're racing toward.
reviews.weakest_line: Try this: post one thing this week that isn't perfect.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA is the same generic 'post something real' advice as Script 1 — give a specific example of what to post (like 'post the listing photo you almost deleted because the lighting was off') so they can actually do it.

reviews.strongest_line: While other agents are overthinking their scripts, their CRM, their branding — she's making fifty more calls.
reviews.weakest_line: Talent is overrated. Consistency is underrated.
reviews.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague — change 'make ten calls' to 'call ten expired listings from last month using this opening line: [specific script].'

reviews.strongest_line: You've been optimizing for speed in a strategy game.
reviews.weakest_line: They're hiring the agent who knows which offer to write, which inspector to trust, which deal to walk from.
reviews.one_line_note: Give one concrete example of what 'judgment over urgency' actually looks like in a real transaction—without it, this is just motivational wallpaper.

reviews.strongest_line: Gen Z isn't broke. They're earning more than any previous generation at their age.
reviews.weakest_line: So ask yourself: Is your online presence built for someone who's never used Google to search?
reviews.one_line_note: The insight is too generic ('cut through the noise') — give one specific tactic for reaching Gen Z buyers, like 'post neighborhood walkthroughs on TikTok' or 'answer DMs within 10 minutes, not 10 hours.'

reviews.strongest_line: You're not too busy to answer. You're too busy because you don't answer.
reviews.weakest_line: While you're chasing the next marketing hack or perfecting your Instagram grid, Karina Chavez built a referral-based empire in Albuquerque on something you learned in kindergarten.
reviews.one_line_note: This is a weaker version of Script 3 with the same guest and same advice — it's redundant and adds nothing new.

reviews.strongest_line: Someone in your sphere just hired another agent. And it feels like a breakup.
reviews.weakest_line: Barry's advice? 'Focus on what you do have, not on what you don't.'
reviews.one_line_note: This is a weaker version of Script 2 with the same guest, same quote, same insight—kill this and keep the roommate hook version.

reviews.strongest_line: Confidence doesn't create action. Action creates confidence.
reviews.weakest_line: And watch what happens.
reviews.one_line_note: This is nearly identical to Script 3—same guest, same quote, same message—kill one or differentiate with a completely different angle.

reviews.strongest_line: You don't need to be the most tech-savvy agent in your market. You just need to be willing to look like a beginner in front of people.
reviews.weakest_line: I do the most. This is my first YouTube live. I'm excited.
reviews.one_line_note: The source quote is too thin—being nervous about a YouTube live isn't a competitive advantage, and the script knows it so it pivots to generic inspiration.

top_10.strongest_line: If you switched brokerages today, how many of your clients would follow you? That number is your real brand equity.
top_10.weakest_line: The brokerage didn't build that trust. You did.
top_10.one_line_note: This is nearly perfect—only tweak is to make the gut check question the actual CTA instead of burying it mid-paragraph.

top_10.strongest_line: The fortune is in the follow-up. And as much as I wish it wasn't, it's the hardest part.
top_10.weakest_line: Because the agents who can't stomach the follow-up? They're the ones wondering why their pipeline's empty.
top_10.one_line_note: Add what specific system Eithan built to force follow-up (calendar block, VA handoff, automated reminder) so viewers know HOW to make it happen.

top_10.strongest_line: Suddenly a $2 million home costs $25K a year just to insure. That's a $2,000 monthly payment your buyer didn't budget for.
top_10.weakest_line: Insurance is killing more deals than bad inspections right now.
top_10.one_line_note: Perfect as-is, but if you want a 10, name one specific carrier Jeff uses or one zip code where he's seen this blow up three deals.

top_10.strongest_line: Because in luxury real estate, you don't get do-overs. You get one shot to show you understand the stakes.
top_10.weakest_line: The agents who close the biggest deals aren't the fastest. They're the ones who ask the right questions before they act.
top_10.one_line_note: Perfect as-is, but if you want a 10, add one specific example of the conversation Jill had that saved a deal (even anonymized).

top_10.strongest_line: A buyer walks in. They've got eight million liquid. They need to close in thirty days. Every agent in the room is salivating.
top_10.one_line_note: This is nearly perfect—only weakness is the generic podcast plug at the end instead of a sharper behavioral CTA.

top_10.strongest_line: Not 'updated kitchen' — 'the kind of kitchen where Sunday mornings stretch into afternoons.'
top_10.weakest_line: D.J. Paris runs business development for a real estate tech company in Chicago.
top_10.one_line_note: This is the best script in the batch — the novelist/journalist persona angle is brilliantly specific and immediately actionable.

top_10.strongest_line: Your college roommate just bought a house. They didn't call you.
top_10.weakest_line: The agents who win? They grieve for five minutes, then get back on the phone.
top_10.one_line_note: Perfect as-is—this hook will stop every new agent mid-scroll and the CTA is immediately actionable.

top_10.strongest_line: The seller had been watching. Testing. Waiting to see if Jay would quit like everyone else.
top_10.weakest_line: He was on a conference call with other agents celebrating wins while he was sitting there broke.
top_10.one_line_note: Perfect as-is—this is the story that stops thumbs and changes behavior.

top_10.strongest_line: The deal that makes you feel invincible is the same one that's about to wreck your next three months.
top_10.one_line_note: Perfect as-is—this will stop thumbs and get saves from agents who've lived this exact cycle.

top_10.strongest_line: That client comment that ruined your whole day? It hit because you already believed it.
top_10.weakest_line: The trigger is actually showing you exactly where the work needs to happen.
top_10.one_line_note: This will get massive engagement from burned-out agents—consider extending it 10 seconds to let the emotional weight land.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Database. Response time. Daily actions. Put it where you'll see it every morning.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: The muck? Interest rates. Inventory. What Zillow's doing. Your competitor's Instagram.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The three controllables need tactical depth—HOW to improve response time, WHAT daily actions, not just naming them.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Imagine one out of every five items at the grocery store all being made by the same company.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: So here's your move: ask yourself what tech, what systems, what training you need to close the gap.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague—name ONE specific tech tool or system they should adopt today, not 'ask yourself.'

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: If you're competing on brokerage brand alone, you just became invisible.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: These agents didn't sign up to be Compass agents. But now? They're operating under a tech-forward company that moves nothing like the legacy brands they joined.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is 90% identical to Script 3—pick one angle (tech gap or personal brand) and commit fully.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Most agents pay for tools. Top producers build them.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: You'll be shocked how fast it happens.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The hook is strong but the middle is too vague—name ONE specific tool he built and show the exact AI prompt he used to build it.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: You're losing deals to agents who aren't better than you. They just show up first on Google.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: That's your starting point.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The advice is too generic—tell them the THREE specific things to fix after they Google themselves (reviews, headshot, website speed, etc.).

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Stop lying to yourself about what building an empire actually takes.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: What are they doing that you're not? What are they NOT doing that you are?
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The insight section is too long and abstract — give one concrete example of what 'alignment' looks like in practice (specific schedule, specific boundary, specific conversation).

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: The resentment you feel? That's not burnout. That's incongruency.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Look at the most successful agents in your market. What are they doing that you're not? What are they NOT doing that you are?
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is too similar to Script 2 (same guest, same theme, same vague questions) — either kill it or find a completely different angle on honest communication with a specific story.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: You're not wrong about your skills yet. You're wrong about your starting point.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Kim Rittberg — six-time award winner, former Netflix marketer, TV producer for a decade — works with agents who know video matters but can't seem to make it work.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The MSR framework gets buried in explanation—show one real agent's before/after mindset shift instead of defining all three steps abstractly.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: That's not failure. That's tuition.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Every piece of advice you've ever gotten is worthless.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The hook overpromises and the insight stays too philosophical—give one specific mistake Jeff made with dollar amounts and exact consequences.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Every mistake became a system. Every failure became a filter.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: The deal that fell apart because he didn't ask the right financing question.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is Script 1 wearing a different hat—pick ONE actual mistake Jeff made with names, numbers, and the system he built from it.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Your $2M listing that got 47 impressions as a photo? Now it's a cinematic walkthrough getting shared by buyers you've never met.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: She uses Auto Real App.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This reads like a paid ad for Auto Real App — either commit to the tool review format or bury the product name deeper and lead with the transformation story.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: When you help someone buy, you're not just closing a deal — you're anchoring a family.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Every rent check is a 100% loss. Not just for your client — for civilization.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The 'civilization' angle is too grand and preachy for stuck intermediates who need tactical wins — reframe around one specific client story where ownership changed their behavior in 90 days.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: You can be the top producer in your market and still be failing at the life you actually want.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Maybe success is 30 transactions and coaching your kid's team. Maybe it's $2M in volume and actually taking Sundays off.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Too vague and self-helpy—give one concrete example of what Garrett ACTUALLY changed in his business (a system, a boundary, a hire) instead of asking viewers to journal.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Your database doesn't trust you because you haven't been consistent long enough.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Drop it in the comments if you're serious.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is a near-duplicate of Script 3 with the same Garrett quote—either kill it or differentiate by focusing on ONE specific lead source he committed to and what happened month by month.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Five focused weeks now is worth three months of catching up later.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Pick three clients you've been meaning to reach out to.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Replace vague 'reach out' with a specific action (text this exact message, mail a market report, invite to coffee with this script).

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: The gap between you and them? It doesn't widen in January. It widens right now.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: This December — make five extra calls a day. That's it. Five.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Five calls to WHO about WHAT—expired listings, past clients, sphere—specificity turns this from a 5 to an 8.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Committed people don't negotiate with circumstances.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Pick one income-producing activity. Do it today. Not Monday. Today.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Name the activity—'call three expireds,' 'door-knock your farm,' 'text ten past clients'—generic IPAs don't move needles.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: People don't want to leave voicemails about six-figure decisions. They want a human. Right now.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Think about the deals you lost because you were 'protecting your time.'
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Add one specific story of a deal Karina won by answering — the 7pm call example is mentioned but not developed into an actual narrative.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Every tenant becomes a future buyer. Every family she helps tells ten more.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: What problem exists in YOUR market that every other agent is ignoring?
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The motel conversion story is interesting but too vague — needs numbers (how many units? what's the ROI? how many referrals actually came from it?).

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: She became THE agent for that world.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Find a niche and leverage your network.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Too generic—show us HOW she actually penetrated the finance world (specific event, conversation, or tactic), not just that she did.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: A resume lists credentials. An About Me video shows personality, shows proof, shows why YOU are the call they should make.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: The agent down the street just stole your listing. And you never saw it coming.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Hook creates a problem that doesn't connect to the solution—start with 'You're invisible on Google and here's the one video that fixes it' instead of a vague competitor threat.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Clients don't buy your marketing stack. They buy your reliability. Your honesty. Your presence.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Show up. Do the work. Be straight with your clients. And success will be inevitable.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The advice is too generic—give one specific example of what 'show up' or 'do the work' actually looks like in Jay's daily routine.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: In a business full of shortcuts, that's actually rare.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Show up. Do the work. Be straight with your clients. And success will be inevitable.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is nearly identical to Script 3—either kill one or differentiate by showing a specific example of Jay doing one of these four things.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Your clients don't actually want to be your friends.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Being likable? That's table stakes.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The insight is solid but needs one concrete example of what professionalism looks like in action—a specific system or response time standard.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Feeling attacked doesn't mean you're weak; it means something inside of you is asking for attention.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Your next level of success doesn't require thicker skin — it requires regulation, presence, and the ability to lead when triggered.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Replace vague leadership language with one specific scenario (e.g., 'when your top agent quits after you dismissed their pricing concern') and give a tactical regulation technique Paul actually teaches.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Right now, you lose clients because you can't serve them past your MLS boundary.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: With a national system, you become the advisor for their entire journey.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is a policy wish, not an actionable insight—pivot to what agents can do NOW with existing tools (Zillow API, referral networks, multi-MLS subscriptions) instead of waiting for NAR to fix it.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: A real estate tech analyst just said the quiet part out loud: it should be harder to become a REALTOR.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Higher standards mean better agents. Better agents mean better outcomes. Better outcomes mean the profession earns respect again.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The insight section is too abstract—add one specific licensing requirement Chris advocates for (hours? exam difficulty? mentorship?) and contrast it with one state's current laughably low bar.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Right now, you're competing with one hand tied behind your back.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: So here's your question: if NAR won't build it, who will?
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The insight section is too long and abstract—cut it in half and add one specific example of what an agent could DO differently with national MLS access tomorrow.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Most burned-out agents aren't doing too much. They're feeling too little.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: She told me if anybody would've said in 1999 that she'd have her name on a shirt sponsoring teams, she wouldn't have believed it.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The little league shirt detail is filler—replace it with a specific story of HOW gratitude changed her behavior in one transaction or tough moment.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Confidence doesn't create action. Action creates confidence.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: And watch what happens.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is nearly identical to Script 3—same guest, same quote, same message—kill one or differentiate with a completely different angle.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: You're not a salesperson. You're the person someone trusts with their entire financial future.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Think about the last client you helped. Not the commission. The actual human. What did you protect them from? Write it down.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague and introspective — give them a specific action they can take with their next client interaction, not homework about their last one.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: We turned a privilege into a grind. A calling into a checklist.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Think about the last client you helped. Not the commission. The actual human. Write down their name.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is nearly identical to Script 1 — same guest, same quote, same vague CTA about 'thinking about your last client' — consolidate or kill one.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: You're losing the deal before you even know they're mad.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: It's like having a negotiation coach reading body language you can't even see over email.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Name the actual AI tool Tim uses—'AI tools that analyze emails' is too generic and kills credibility.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Your buyer just asked if they could write a letter to the seller's dead mother.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: That's not a client problem. That's the job.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The hook is killer but the script never delivers on it—give us one real story from an agent who saw this level of crazy, not just book summary.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: What if the thing your clients actually need isn't more perfection? What if they need someone who'll tell them the truth about what's real?
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Your clients don't know what real looks like anymore.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The hook is too vague and the insight section tries to cover too much ground — pick one specific example (either the client's Pinterest obsession OR the agent's perfection trap, not both) and drill into it with a concrete story.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: The rage isn't anger at clients. It's anger at the impossible standard you're racing toward.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Try this: post one thing this week that isn't perfect.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The CTA is the same generic 'post something real' advice as Script 1 — give a specific example of what to post (like 'post the listing photo you almost deleted because the lighting was off') so they can actually do it.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: While other agents are overthinking their scripts, their CRM, their branding — she's making fifty more calls.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Talent is overrated. Consistency is underrated.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague — change 'make ten calls' to 'call ten expired listings from last month using this opening line: [specific script].'

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: But every hour you wait, someone with half your knowledge and twice your hustle is closing YOUR deal.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Intelligence is a head start. Work ethic is the whole race.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: This is the third script using the same quote — kill two of them or differentiate the angles completely because right now they're cannibalizing each other.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: They don't need you to move fast — they need you to interpret clearly.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: Ask yourself: are you still selling speed, or are you selling clarity?
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The insight is strong but the CTA is a thought exercise — give them one specific thing to say differently on their next listing appointment.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Your buyers aren't walking away from the house. They're walking away from you.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: The most effective agents? They present pricing as a narrative.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The hook promises a punch but the insight gets vague—show exactly what 'pricing as a narrative' looks like with a real example from Carrie's deals.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: You've been optimizing for speed in a strategy game.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: They're hiring the agent who knows which offer to write, which inspector to trust, which deal to walk from.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: Give one concrete example of what 'judgment over urgency' actually looks like in a real transaction—without it, this is just motivational wallpaper.

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Your brain reads it as danger. And it pulls you back to what's familiar. What's safe. What's predictable.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: And that's what memory reconsolidation and hypnosis actually do — they update the code.
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The CTA is too vague ('what behavior keeps showing up') — give one specific example pattern that burned-out veterans will recognize instantly (like avoiding follow-up calls or saying yes to every client).

needs_rewrite.strongest_line: Gen Z isn't broke. They're earning more than any previous generation at their age.
needs_rewrite.weakest_line: So ask yourself: Is your online presence built for someone who's never used Google to search?
needs_rewrite.one_line_note: The insight is too generic ('cut through the noise') — give one specific tactic for reaching Gen Z buyers, like 'post neighborhood walkthroughs on TikTok' or 'answer DMs within 10 minutes, not 10 hours.'

killed.strongest_line: You don't need to be the most tech-savvy agent in your market. You just need to be willing to look like a beginner in front of people.
killed.weakest_line: I do the most. This is my first YouTube live. I'm excited.
killed.one_line_note: The source quote is too thin—being nervous about a YouTube live isn't a competitive advantage, and the script knows it so it pivots to generic inspiration.

killed.strongest_line: You're not too busy to answer. You're too busy because you don't answer.
killed.weakest_line: While you're chasing the next marketing hack or perfecting your Instagram grid, Karina Chavez built a referral-based empire in Albuquerque on something you learned in kindergarten.
killed.one_line_note: This is a weaker version of Script 3 with the same guest and same advice — it's redundant and adds nothing new.

killed.strongest_line: Someone in your sphere just hired another agent. And it feels like a breakup.
killed.weakest_line: Barry's advice? 'Focus on what you do have, not on what you don't.'
killed.one_line_note: This is a weaker version of Script 2 with the same guest, same quote, same insight—kill this and keep the roommate hook version.
